description.text:
this is fully automatic, heavy duty, filament feeder!
it uses the motor from the automated build-platform to turn the spindle.
when the extruder has extruded enough filament and thus shortened the distance between the extruder and the spindle, a little switch is activated that gives a short impuls to a motor-control circuitry (also designed and prototyped by myself) which lets the motor run for about 1 second - enough for some minutes of printing...
(this motor-control also has a two-way switch for manual control of the motor and two indicator LEDs - green: forward, red: backward)
--- I did this because of problems with a very heavy spindle that I have where the extruder constantly has its problems turning the spindle on its own;
now I can do unattended prints of even the highest, biggest objects!

description.header:
there are three main parts building this thing:
A) the engine - this is the block housing the motor and everything related (gears, spindle-holder); 6 printed parts, some other things involved (nuts & bolts and such)
B) the controller - this parts holds the motor-control circuitry; 4 printed parts and some electronics
C) the end-switch box - here sits the end-switch that operates the motor; 3 printed parts.

some words before going into detail:
I did this mostly with parts I had rotting in some really old boxes where I didn't look into for the last 15 years (at least); so maybe you have some trouble getting exactly the same - this doesn't matter at all, your's don't need to look exactly as mine ;-)
I've included the OpenScad script for everything, so if even the mechanical dimensions of my original work don't fit your material, go and change it at will...
(above said is mostly valid for the two-way switch for manually operating the motor; it seems the "c&k Rocker J3" switch comes pretty close - although the mounting-holes seem larger)
everything is metric (sorry, I'm German...)
description.text:
A) Engine
material needed:
1x bolt M8x30
1x washer M8
1x lock-nut M8
4x machine-bolt M5x30
4x washer M5
4x lock-nut M5
1x threaded rod M10x165
7x nut M10
4x ball-bearing #6000 (10x26x8 mm)
1x gear-motor incl. screws (from automated build-platform)
the M8 stuff is needed to fix the engine to the TOM body
the M10 stuff is needed for the spindle-axis
the M5 stuff is to hold the engine-housing together
I also recommend to put some "screw paint" (I don't know the correct english word, it's a paint to put on screws to protect the nuts from getting lose) for some extra protection...
see pictures, please ensure that the little gear from the motor does not touch the body of the big gear, only the teeth should have contact... Attention

author: my-3D

title: Printrbot Shock Absorbing Feet / Bench Mount

description.text:
I ran across vitaminjosh's "Printrbot Simple Vibration Dampener" (Thing ID 184821) and decided to give it a go.  It worked well for its intended use, but I wanted more stability than the original design offered, so I decided to utilize part of the design to make bench mounts for my printrbot.  Simply adding bench mounts to the end of the original design would've made it too long for most stock printrbots, so I opted to make individual pieces for each corner.  This design is what I came up with.  ALL feedback is welcomed including constructive criticism. If you make one, share a photo!
I will be uploading a revised version shortly to account for issues with the upper screw holes where it mounts to the printer.  (Essentially increasing the depth of the channel and raising the location of the screw holes).

Printrbot

Simple Black

Doesn't Matter

Yes

30%

I've had the best luck printing these with supports at 0.1mm layer height @ 30% infill. A brim helps with bed adhesion. Would recommend using ABS considering it is a structural design.

comments.text: I've designed this with a clearance of 0.3 or 0.5mm, not that sure. May i suggest callibrating your layer thickness (or perhaps your axis) ? I have no idea how accurate your printer is, but it should normally fit (It did for me). Or you could just sand down the pins a bit. I've already changed it to thicker pins (pins snapped to easy) for the candle version of this (same but with a wick hole). I might also change my new candle mold so it can be used for chocolate.

comments.author: Joey_3D

comments.text: Aha it took a long time before i figured out i had too calibrate my E axis too :)  You should measure the fillament going in and use a formula too calculate a new value for the eeprom, then you should callibrate the Z, X and Y by prinding a 20x20x20mm cube. Next you should print a part that is square on one end and a cirkle on the other (that's the one i use (idk which one in perticular)). This part is only one layer thick and makes it easy to measure the thickness of one layer. With this you should be able to callibrate it by changing the extruded fillament multiplier in the slicing software you use. This last step should be done with every diffrent spool of filament if you are really anal about it. This is so because the thickness of the fillament can vary spool by spool.. 3mm could be 2.85mm or 2.80mm etc. I also think it changes if it takes up moisture by laying in open air for too long.

This OpenSCAD program generates left and right covers for the X-Carve Y motor pulley assembly. This is required as the X-Carve CNC machine tends to generate  dust and chips, and these get caught in the Y motor belt assembly. These covers help to keep some of the chips and dust away from the assembly.
The covers are attached by using longer screws on the idler pulleys, and then a second nylock nut to hold the covers on.

author: barrstudent

description.text:
This is my newest Raspberry Pi portable.
Built around the Raspberry Pi Zero it measures just 6.9cm x 4.8cm x 2.7cm making it the smallest portable Raspberry pi I've ever seen, perhaps the smallest ever created! It runs Retropie Emulationstation, which provides a wide variety of emulators from the first Atari all the way to the GBA, N64 and even Dreamcast. It also features a 1.5" OLED from Adafruit, which is running using FBCP and a custom configuration I wrote for it. If the built in screen seems too small, or if you want to play a multi player game you can always connect it to a full sized tv through HDMI. Unfortunately it does not have any speakers built in, since the Raspberry pi Zero does not feature any analog sound output. You do however get sound, when it's plugged into the tv. The built in controller is connected through the GPIO, and configured using the Adafruit Retrogame script. If you want one of these yourself you can of course attempt to build one using the files on this Thingiverse page, or you can buy one from me ([email protected]) Parts List: Raspberry pi Zero with essentials:
https://www.pi-supply.com/product/raspberry-pi-zero-cable-kit/?v=dd65ef9a5579 Adafruit 1.5" OLED display:
https://www.pi-supply.com/product/adafruit-oled-breakout-board-16-bit-color-1-5-wmicrosd-holder/?v=dd65ef9a5579 1200 mah battery:

The original part was 0 degrees, and my default version is 45 degrees.

Print and clip on like the picture!
If needed, adjust the fan_angle variable at the top of the scad script, and print a new version for yourself.

author: notcarlitobeto

title: Flash Forge Creator X Naked conversion

description.text:
THis is a conversion for the older FlashForge Creator X printers with the worlds most annoying SD card placement. It is hidden behind the front panel off to one side, and makes it a real pain in the butt to get in and out. This conversion eliminates the whole front panel, and allows a huge amount of access to your print from the front. It gets rid of the problem of trying to access the SD card, and also allows you to easily find dropped parts and hardware. Cleaning scraps out of the bottom is much easier after this mod as well. I have removed all outer panels on our PLA printers to aid in cleaning, cooling, and part access.There are three screen cover designs, one robot-esque, one plain,and one plain with no button recess. Iges versions of all files are uploaded as well.
One screen cover also has a port for a front mount power switch. If wired correctly, you don't have to reach around back to turn on/off the printer. The recess fits the following switch:
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00XBG1SJW?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=od_aui_detailpages00

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Notes: The parts are designed to print face down with support. There is built in support at the button hole, and the screw hole to assure support right at the edge. These can be broken out afterward. In if you are using support in Makerbot Desktop, I recommend a "Support Model Spacing" setting of 1mm for clean breakaway.

This is a colorimeter that relies on LEDs for both the light source and measurement.

Below is a detailed description of the assembly of a colorimeter suitable for use in an introductory chemistry course. Using plastic pieces made with a 3D printer along with some minimal wiring supplies, it is possible to construct this device for around five dollars. This guide is designed to allow anyone with access to a 3D printer to make a colorimeter, and to that end assumes only a very limited knowledge of 3D printing as well as very basic wiring skills. No soldering is necessary and the only tool needed is a screwdriver. Materials: • Plastic housing – 3 pieces
• AA battery case with on/off switch
• 2 AA batteries
• 400 ohm resister
• 5 screws (#4 x 3/8 inch pan Phillips for metal)
• Banana socket
• Electrical Tape
• 3 small wire nuts
• 5mm LED
• 10mm red LED
• Voltmeter The files required for printing the plastic portions are Mendez – Colorimeter-Top.stl, Mendez –Colorimeter - Center.stl, and Mendez – Colorimeter - Bottom.stl. The colorimeter described here was printed on a Makerbot Mini with standard settings (2 shells, 20% infill and 0.2mm layer height). Circuit
The operation of this device is based on two circuits. In the first, two batteries are used to power a source LED. The light from this LED induced a voltage change in the detector LED that is measured by a voltmeter. Assembly
Step 1 - Begin assembly by placing the battery case into the bottom casing, making sure to line up the switch on the bottom with the opening on the casing. The wiring should stick up near the corner without any screw holes. Step 2 - Thread the wiring from the battery case through the large hole in the middle casing piece. The middle casing piece should sit on the inner ledge of the bottom casing with the three screw holes lining up. Carefully screw in the three screws. None of the holes in either the middle or bottom casings are threaded, so some force may be required to start the screws. Be careful not to create new holes while screwing, which could disrupt the alignment of the other screws. Step 3 – Insert the source LED in the smaller hole in the middle casing. Applying some pressure with your thumb may be necessary but it should snap into place. Spread the wires apart and use electrical tape to ensure they stay apart. Make sure that both wires are unobstructed and still accessible for later steps. Step 4 - Using the wire connectors, connect the red wire to the negative terminal of the LED (the short one). Next connect the resister to the black wire and then to the positive terminal of the LED. Do not turn on the battery without a resistor connected; this could burn out the LED. Step 5 - Now is a good time to test the system. Turn on the battery case and look for a light. Remember, LEDs are not multi-directional; if the wiring is switched, it will not work. Assemble the detector apparatus by attaching the 10mm LED to the banana socket. The short lead of the LED should be connected to the red, while the long lead should connect to the black. Step 6 - Insert the 10mm LED into the larger opening on the middle casing piece. Like the source LED, it should snap into place but may require applying pressure. Use electrical tape to ensure it stays in place while you place the cover on in the next step. Step 7 - Carefully place the top casing piece on top, lining up the openings for the cuvette and banana socket. You may need to slightly adjust the angle of the banana socket but once the cover is on, the banana socket should be stable. There is plenty of room for the wiring, but you may need to move the source LED wiring so that it does not stick out the sides. Secure the top to the middle with two screws, being careful to line up the holes. Step 8 - Once the case is on, connect it to a multimeter and test the device. If everything is working, you should read a voltage around 1V with a blank cuvette in the holder. Additional Considerations:
• While any 5mm LED in the visible spectrum should work, the resistor and battery described above are tuned for conventional 5mm red and green LEDs. Other LEDs may turn on but may not be bright enough to register on the detector.
• The intensity of the light and the range of source LEDs can be modified by adding or removing resistors or changing the voltage of the batteries.
• A 10mm cuvette can hold around 3ml of liquid, but because the LEDs are so low in the device, only 1ml is actually required.
• While the top of the cuvette remains open, this was found to have no noticeable effect on the resulting absorbance data.
• If the voltage reading on the multimeter is negative, then you probably switched the wiring on the detector. This is fine for the detector, but the source LED will not turn on if wired incorrectly.

remixed_from.author: Xendi
remixed_from.title: 40 mm fan mount for Printrbot Simple V2

description.text:
This is a dual fan bracket for the Printrbot, the fan on the right is connected directly to the PSU and spins 100% of the time. This keeps the metal hotend cool to the touch, stopping the filament from getting soft and creating jams. The fan on the left is just the normal printrbot fan, because is is offset to the left a little bit I created a small deflector. Parts
5 3M x 30MM (25MM if you don't want to use fan guards) bolts and 3M x 18(Stock)
1 40mm fan
1 Molex to fan adapter (http://www.amazon.com/Zalman-ZM-MC1-Multi-connector-Add-Fan/dp/B000FAKUE6/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1455216813&sr=8-1&keywords=molex+to+fan)
Some extra wire to extend the fan wire.

title: Thing-O-Matic Reel and Filament Control System

description.text:
Here is a very simple system with a number of advantages:
No gluing is necessary for assembly; parts snap or push together.
The Reel Arms allow two 8 inch reels to hang from a side or back of Thing-O-Matic or, for color freaks, on all three sides at once! That's six reels!
Filament won't easily spill off the reels and, if it does, it's trapped inside the arms and readily reloads.
The Filament Guide Arm can be positioned facing in or out of the frame, and the Filament Guide Tip on top of it swivels. I like to use it as shown, which gives the filament a very smooth path. Friction is not a problem; filament pulls off the reel with virtually no effort, and the reel turns on the rod very freely.
All parts clip onto the frame of the Thing-O-Matic and need no fasteners.
The whole thing sets up and takes down in seconds and stores in very little space.
It includes a Filament Clip (derived from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:12516) to hold an idle filament to the reel.

The Reel Arms are a very tight fit on a 110mm x 110mm build platform and the Filament Guide Arm requires 106mm in the Z plane. You may have to move the arms around a bit to get them on.
I've put each part on separate .stl files and the full arm/guide/clip assembly on its own file.
Print all parts using 0 extra shells and 100% fill. The reel arms and the guide arm will need minor cleanups within the openings that build vertically.
The bar sitting across the arms should be approximately 1 inch in diameter by 12 inches long. The extra length allows you to grab it outside the arms when holding two reels and load it more easily with just one reel.
The end caps help prevent the bar from slipping out of the arms and also help the appearance; a bar of any material will look raw without them. You may have to increase or decrease the size in your slicer to get them to fit your material. I used a wood dowel, nominally 1 inch but measuring 7/8 inch in diameter.
Assembly:
The Filament Guide Tip snaps onto the top of the Filament Guide Arm, which then slides into the clip. It's a bit easier to push the clip onto the frame first, then decide which way the arm faces and slide it into the clip.
The Reel Arms are pushed onto the sides of the frame, with the top edges level with one of the T-slots in the top or center of the frame opening. Those are the strongest places, though you can clip them on at any height.
I jammed on the end caps by shaving the edges on the dowel ends a little, placing one cap lying flat on a hard surface, setting the dowel into it, placing the other cap on top of the dowel, and whaling away with a hammer. For a less compressible material, make them a slip fit and glue on.
About that Filament Clip: When you pull a filament out of the extruder, push the end into the hole, bend it a bit to hold it in, and clip it to the side of the reel. When you use the reel again, TAKE OFF THE CLIP rather than just pulling out the filament. The clip (or anything) projecting from the reel as it rotates will likely find something to hang on!

comments.text: Not bad - I like the filament arm guide so I printed this over the derivative work (which excludes the crane).

description.text:
A remix of a great design by 4volt Added length to handles. Any 1/4" hex bit can be used. I push the bit in just after the print is finished while it's on the bed and still hot. PLA material will allow additional fit adjustment with hot water. I just drop it into water that was brought to a boil in the microwave. I sometimes scale up the 38mm LongBit Handle so I can tell the difference. Complete instructions can be found at: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:137367 Up Date 4.9.16:
Uploaded handles v2.1 with slight chamfer on the opening for easier bit install. (like butter)
Added a 2x long handle 50 mm long & a 20 mm spacer. Can use longer handle with short bit + spacer. Can cut spacer to length. Magnetizer / Demagnetizer can be found on eBay. Please add you location to you profile. I'm always wondering?

author: uchavez

description.text:
An assortment of 3 different style (4 different 3D models as of writing) of Front Grips for the Intratec Tec-9 Firearm. As you can see from the final image, I have gone through many prototypes to get to the models seen here today. I've always wanted a front grip for my Tec-9, but due to the incredibly silly gun laws it is illegal to put a vertical front grip on a "pistol". Magpul made their interesting Angled Front Grip but it would not fit the Tec-9's odd setup, so I decided to make my own. What you are seeing is the very first ever horizontal and angled front grips for the Tec-9 firearm. I've never seen another like it, and have never even seen a picture of a Tec-9 with anything other than the illegal Vertical front grip. 1st up is Version 6 and probably my favorite as seen printed in Black PLA.
This is a sort of vertical grip which snugly mounts around the take-down pin just under the barrel and in front of the magazine area. You are going to want to turn this one upright for printing as seen in the Cura image of it above. It's important to understand that I do not know the legality of this model, so use at your own risk. And please don't flag it. The model, nor a printed version is not in any way illegal, only when attaching it to a firearm may it be an issue. IMO I'd say it's fine as it's not a protruding vertical grip as it's attached and simply extends the body. As well this does not bolt on in any way and simply is held on by pressure, so it can't be considered a permanently mounted vertical fore grip. So use at your own risk! 2nd up is Version 5 Super Long as seen printing in Black PLA.
This is a MP5 style horizontal front grip for the Tec-9. It is setup so the dismantle pin will slide into the grooves and be locked into place. While there is a hole setup so you can install a screw and nut on the underside of the vented (holed) barrel shroud to securely mount it in place. The left side also has a thumb groove to it for right handed shooters. I may upload the version without this groove at a later date if it is wanted. It actually fits pretty snugly over the dismantle pin area and barrel shroud, so you might not need to bolt it down. I've yet to bolt my down as getting to a nut on the inside to mount it to a barrel shroud hole is difficult. The grip extends pretty much to the front edge of the barrel shroud. I've also yet to fire the gun with any of the included grips, so will update when I have. 3rd is the Version 5 Long (non-super) which is shorter in length, as seen printed in Blue PLA.
Personally I like the Super Long version better, but I've put this here in case people want to try it out. 4th up is Version 4, the Angled Front Grip.
I started on this one first, and didn't fully like the feel so moved on to Version 5. I might revisit it and try to make it more comfortable in the future, but for the time being it is there for you to try out. Only been modelling for a handful weeks now, so I'm sure they're not all perfect, but it fits my Tec-9 quite well and adds a good bit of comfort to two hand shooting with it. Not responsible for how you use this. Please no commercial uses or selling of this model. Otherwise enjoy!

title: Tudor Rose Box hinge panel set 2mm hole for 1.75mm filament

description.text:
Enlarged the pin holes to 2mm diameter so no post-processing required to fit the 1.75mm filament as a hinge pin.
96 point circles were used instead of the default 24 point circles in sketchup for better printing and detail. Also made the "pin" hole go through the part completely so a single piece of 1.75mm filament may be used instead of 2 smaller pieces (less parts = less frustration) Just printed mine and the fitment is near perfect!

title: Prusa i3 Leadscrew Z axis upgrade with Endcap - Remix

description.text:
The issue I am trying to resolve is X-axis belt tension. I added an endcap to this the right side of the X Axis Assembly. It is a simple integrated endcap. I wanted to take tension off of the Z Axis rods. 
This is a remix of a part designed by eried.

comments.text: This did not work for me on the HICTop 3dp-11 printer. The reason is that the Z Lead Screw does not have a socket for the 8MM nut that came with the printer. I had to solve this a different way. This should work for anyone using a more traditional lead screw setup on a Prusa i3 printer.

author: porcej

title: Dominion Sleeved Card Tray/Holder Snapable and Stackable - Remixed to fit sleeved cards

description.text:
Popsicle_peon made an awesome set of holders for Dominion but I sleeved my cards so they wouldn't fit, so as my first ever 3D printing project I modified them to print big enough to hold the cards of my set, sleeved with Standard Mayday Sleeves. Now I store all the base cards and the 4 player assembled player decks in these for super quick and easy setup and take down of under 2 minutes! Not counting the kingdom cards. I made these to hold cards for up to 4 players and not 6 like the original, also I made the copper and estate trays the right size for when actually playing so you do need to have the 4 player hands assembled and stored in the kingdom cards trays instead of with the other coppers and estates. For a complete set print:
15 holders for Platinum/Kingdom/Victory cards: 7mm,
2 Holders for Curse and Gold cards: 16.5mm,
2 Holders for Copper and Trash: 17mm,
1 Holder for Silver: 20mm,
1 or 2 bowls for tokens, (see below update)
1 or 2 tokens lids
and 2 card tray Lids. (A third of my way through printing these I added a slight inward curve to the open edges to more easily grab the bottom cards, so some in the picture has a straight edge and others have a curved.) They stack perfectly with only 1mm difference in 2 side by side stacks with all the big holders stacked with 2 7mm holders on top, and the other 13 7mm holders on the other side. I still haven't made the lids totally snug but I increased the width by .1mm from what I printed so hopefully they'll be a bit snugger. Have fun with Dominion! Update: Right after publishing this I had the idea of making a connectable bowl for the tokens used with some cards, so I modified the original post's 16mm card tray to be a bowl, then I duplicated & enlarged it to connect with the ones I made. I then a week later made a second version with a special lid for holding the tokens in the tray when stacked. The Bottom 3 files are for people who are printing the original trays for unsleeved cards. I recommend 200microns for the first version to get a smoother bowl curve, also I suggest 10% infill, I printed with 5% infill, I think it's okay but when printing I saw the outside edge of the bowl had almost no support with such large hexagons and it frayed a little more than I like, in the future I'll print with 10% infill to provide more internal bowl support, but if you need to save those 5 grams... Then 5% is okay. For the 2nd version of the token bowls, I made it a more vertical angle for the side of the bowl, so now 300 Microns should be fine and 5% infill should be fine too. Also the coins can come out of version 1 when stacked with the other trays even when cards are above them, so I reduced the internal structure height and made a modified top to keep the tokens in without effecting stack-ability. Have fun fellow dominion lovers!

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

300 Microns

Infill:

10 - 20%

comments.text: So, what is the actual inside  size of the trays? What kind of sleeves do they support??
comments.author: Levgrada

comments.text: 63X97 mm approximately. They work well for the Mayday Euro size card sleeves (MDG-7028).
comments.author: Levgrada

comments.text: I'm in the process of printing a full set of these now.  After sleeving my cards they wouldn't fit in the original box any more so I'm printing a full set of 7mm holders for all the kingdom cards, in addition to just the 10 trays for the in-play kingdom cards.  I'll post an "I Made One" when finished.  So far the fit is excellent and after I came back and re-read about pulling out 4 players' worth of cards I realized why I had too many coppers and estates to fit in the 7mm trays.

title: Straight Metal Jacket - With inset mounts

description.text:
I want to mount metal bars onto wood, or other structures, without having to drill holes in the metal bars, or rather, I want to mount them with a bit of an offset.
This thing is a slight modification of the original.  I added a taper to the mounting holes so that when I use screws with a taper, they won't split the plastic.

1) Print a few, either of the slip-through kind, or end caps.
2) Screw them to something solid
3) Slip metal bar in as rail
4) Mount things on the metal bar, like plastic bins

This large (274 mm high) lamp can hold either a white (pictured) or colored LED light in it's base. description.text: This is a font of polygon-based glyphs, for use in OpenSCAD with Spiff.scad. Check out Spiff.scad for instructions for how to use this. This font was originally made in November 2011 with an impractical spiffsans_puts routine that has since been overhauled in favor of two better approaches. The design of this font takes several aesthetic cues from br3ttb's blocky Small Side Font. The two fonts are metric-compatible. You can find the YAML description file on this project's Github: https://github.com/stuartpb/spiffsans
Use Spiff.scad's write function.

comments.text: so the 45degree angles print well?  one of the issues I was trying to solve was that when skeining the hole vs the text, angles and curves would be interpreted slightly differently, resulting in a hole that was too small and text that was too big, or vice versa.

author: PickyBiker

description.text: I was looking for a unique way to show the effects of drag to students in the rocketry unit besides using the conventional parachute or streamer. Inspired by seeds falling out of a maple tree ( Watching them rotate their way slowly down towards my gutters) I though why not helicopter blades. Did some research, saw some good ideas, and this is what I came up with. The rocket will accept ESTES model rocket engines A,B,and C. I'm happy with the looks but think its could be lighter.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Standard

Infill:

Standard

Notes: Engine holder has supports in the stl file spaced 0.005" below the fin brackets. (they snap off easily) When Printing the Body fins it wouldn't hurt the add supports. I didn't but ended up with a functional but less than perfect print.

I wanted to make this design so it could be put together without glue. This is why there are threads and barb fittings on the body sections and pins. It may also help to SLIGHTLY warm the barbed section of the body and pins with a hairdryer if printed in PLA to make them less brittle when pushing them into place. You may also want to add a little glue to the bottom fins once they are in the right spot or use a soldering iron to make a small weld to secure them in place. You'll have to do a little sanding to make sure the fit between parts is good. Although it shouldn't be to much as I played with tolerances as I was printing and reprinting parts.

This is a rocket that doesn't need a parachute for recovery because it has three helicopter blades that will create drag and slow its decent back to the ground much like those wonderful maple seeds we clean out of our gutters every year. It was designed on Solidworks  (and redesigned more than once) then printed on a replicator 2.

Project: Model Rocketry To Objectives: Upon competition of this unit students should be able to
  • Understand Newton’s laws of physics
  • Understand the concepts of an action reaction engine and thrust
  • Understand the concepts of drag (controlling and recovery systems of a rocket.
  • Understand the stages in the flight of a rocket.
    • o Audiences: This would be suitable for grades 7,8 Technology education classes or science classes
    o Preparation: At this point in the year Students have been working with solid works for half the year and have become or should be familiar with the program. Students should have an understanding of the principles behind rocket flight. I use this PowerPoint as a lecture tool.
    Rocketry power point
    https://drive.google.com/file/d/0ByqQhIB1DIDDTkxyd1ZYdEZtVVU/view?usp=sharing
    o Steps!
    1) Introduce the unit of rocketry to the students
    2) Teach the principles of flight using the above PP
    3) Have students sketch out a design of a custom rocket they would like to build. (must include an engine mount, launch lug, recovery system of any kind parachute and streamers are popular, and nose cone)
    4) Once sketches are approved students can design their rocket on solid works (or other software) from sketch.
    5) Completed plans are then built or better yet printed!
    6) Take outside and fly! Results: At the end of this unit Students should have Designed and produced a model rocket. They should Understand the objectives listed above. As a check for understanding have students reflect on their rocket in a typed paper that answers these questions.
  • What was good about it?
  • What could be better if I designed it again?
  • Who’s in class went the highest? Why do you think that was?
  • Who had the most unique rocket in class? Did it work well? Why or Why not?
  • And any other open questions that would apply
    ell us more...
